ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

CTI Foods recognizes the companys responsibility in ensuring the safety of the public, its employees, the environment, equipment, and property.  This commitment is reflected in a comprehensive accidental release prevention program that addresses the design, installation, operation, maintenance, and employee training associated with the ammonia refrigeration system at the CTI Foods facility in Wilder, Idaho.

It is the policy of CTI Foods to ensure that controls are in place to limit the risks of potential ammonia releases.  CTI Foods maintains a safety committee whose members include the designated emergency coordinators for the facility.  The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  The policy is reviewed and updated as needed to ensure it remains an accurate reflection of the facilitys policies regarding evacuation and the protocol to deal with emergency scenarios.

CTI Foods coordinates emergency response efforts with the local fire department and with the contracted refrigeration operations and maintenance firm.  In the case of an ammonia-related emergency, it is the policy of CTI Foods to evacuate and to allow the fire department/HazMat Team to respond to the emergency.  The CTI Foods Maintenance Manager as well as the ammonia refrigeration contractor will be available for guidance and assistance.

One of the activities associated with the plants safety program has been the development and implementation of accidental release prevention and emergency response programs which are designed to comply with OSHAs Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals), and EPAs Risk Management Program regulation (Risk Management Programs for Chemical Accident

al Release Prevention).  The Vice President of Operations and the Corporate EHS Manager are responsible for implementation of the PSM and RMP policies aimed at reducing the risks associated with the ammonia refrigeration system.


STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

CTI Foods processes, packages, and distributes fresh meat products and uses anhydrous ammonia refrigeration systems for freeze tunnels, storage, and plant cooling.  It is located at 22303 US Highway 95, just north of Wilder, Idaho.

The ammonia refrigeration system at the CTI Foods facility has a maximum intended inventory of ~83,000 pounds of ammonia.  It is a closed-loop system with no planned emissions or releases of ammonia.  Ammonia is used as the primary refrigerant, which means it is used as a vehicle to remove heat from the various refrigeration applications including product freezers, cold storage evaporators, and chiller heat exchangers.

There is one mechanical equipment room that includes both East Compressor Room, and West Compressor Room (partially divided by a wall).  It houses refrigeration equipment, including ammonia compressors, pumps, and pressure vessels.  Various recirculator packages, chillers, heat exchangers, and evaporators + freezers are also located throughout the plant.  The Condensers are located outside on the facility roof.

Refrigeration process equipment at the facility operates continuously on demand.  The compressors and condensers cycle on and off to address system heat loads during operation.

When heat is absorbed by the liquid refrigerant (ammonia), it vaporizes (changes phase), and is then compressed by the compressors.  The resulting high pressure ammonia vapor is routed to the condensers, where fans and sprayed water are used to reject latent heat in the ammonia vapor, causing it to condense to a liquid.

Multiple pump recirculator packages at different temperatures / pressures are utilized for the various refrigeration applications at the facility th

at include evaporators for cold / freezer storage rooms and docks, product freezers, and chiller heat exchangers that cool secondary coolants (water + glycol).

Several auxiliary systems are in place to support the operational and safety requirements of the ammonia refrigeration system including:  ammonia leak detection, purgers to remove non-condensible gasses (i.e., air), pressure relief system, machinery room ventilation system, and a refrigeration control system.


ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

To deal with the risks involved with ammonia refrigeration, policies and programs have been developed for the CTI Foods facility (as well as the companys nationwide network of similar plants) to limit the risks of an accidental ammonia release and/or minimize the consequences of a significant ammonia release, fires, explosions, and other types of catastrophic accidents.

Policies developed for the PSM and RMP programs include employee participation, process safety information, process hazard analysis, standard operating procedures, training, management of change + pre-startup safety review, mechanical integrity (inspections / testing / maintenance), hot work permit, contractor management, and incident investigation.  To help coordinate the various elements of the program, a management system has been established that defines responsible parties for the facility to ensure upkeep and implementation of each policy within the RMP and PSM programs.  Compliance Audits are also conducted every 3 years that can identify potential gaps in compliance and recommend actions to achieve full compliance.

Several departments within the facility (Refrigeration, Maintenance, and Safety) as well as outside resources (Ammonia Refrigeration Contractor, and a Risk Management Consultant) help to ensure the appropriate and ongoing implementation (with recordkeeping) of the various elements of the programs.  PSM Team Meetings include discussions r

egarding outstanding corrective action items, planned design changes to the ammonia system (if any), changes in personnel, reviewing evacuation drill results, etc.  Any significant issues that are identified are brought to plant leadership to ensure appropriate resources are allocated for timely resolutions.

The ultimate goal for CTI Foods PSM/RMP program is to prevent accidental releases of ammonia, injuries / illnesses, and to avoid adverse impacts to the environment.  These programs enable our facility to operate the refrigeration system safely because they are based on the rules, procedures, and guidelines that govern our ammonia refrigeration system, as well as the broader ammonia refrigeration industry throughout the country.  In the event of an ammonia release, the emergency response plan is coordinated with the City of Wilder Fire Department, as well as the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).

The ammonia refrigeration system and the associated safety features were designed in accordance with contemporary codes and standards.  The RMP responsible personnel (with guidance from contractors and consultants) also routinely review Recognized and Generally Accepted Good Engineering Practices (RAGAGEP) for the ammonia refrigeration industry to ensure that the facility is properly maintained, and appropriate adjustments are made based on evolving industry standards.


FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

EPAs RMP regulation defines accident as the following: 

The release must be from a covered process and involve a regulated substance held above its threshold quantity in the process. The release must have caused at least one of the following: 

  --  On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (§68.42(a)); or
  --  Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (§68.42(a)).

An investigation into the facilitys accident history revealed that there have been no significant ammonia releases

over the past five years (October 2019  October 2024) that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds within 24 hours or that meet the EPA reporting criteria for the Five-Year Accident History as specified above.  In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from an ammonia release at the facility.


EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

An emergency planning and response policy has been developed at the CTI Foods facility and is maintained by the EHS Department.  It is based on OSHAs requirements for Emergency Action Planning, as well as EPAs Emergency Response Plan.

Facility personnel receive annual training regarding the emergency response procedures and the evacuation plan.  In the event that an ammonia leak is discovered, the person nearest to the leak will alert any personnel in the immediate area who are unaware of the danger, maintenance personnel, and/or their supervisor.  Maintenance personnel will determine what procedures and personnel are necessary to remedy the problem.  All employees evacuate to the designated evacuation assembly areas.  Notifications of response agencies as well as the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) is also detailed the Emergency Response policy.  The CTI Foods facility also has an established relationship with the local Wilder Fire Department who may be called in to assist depending on the scope of an emergency situation.

The Emergency Action Plan policy contains procedures detailing how the facility will react to accidental ammonia releases and other emergencies such as fires, earthquakes, power outages, etc.  This policy has been coordinated with the local emergency service agencies including:  the City of Wilder Fire Department, and the Canyon County LEPC.

The facilitys Emergency Action / Response Policy includes the following elements:

  --  Key Facility Personnel and Responsibilities
  --  Outside Agency Notification Contact Information
  --  Detailed Action Plans for Internal Departments
  --  First

Aid Procedures
  --  Emergency Medical Treatment Procedures
  --  Evacuation Plans + Assembly Areas
  --  Description for Handling Small Ammonia Releases
  --  Details of Outside Assistance Available 
  --  Incident Command System
  --  Initial and Refresher Training

Evacuation drills are also organized and conducted annually by the Safety Department to supplement the training received by all employees at the facility.  As facility management strives to improve safety at the facility, evaluations are documented with suggested improvements, and other observations from the drills.


PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

CTI Foods has worked to address safety issues as they arise in a continued effort to ensure a safe working environment.  Compliance Audits, PHA studies, Mechanical Integrity Inspections, in addition to routine PSM/RMP Meetings have generated recommendations to improve safety and compliance at the facility.  These include enhancing employee training policies, revising standard operating procedures, improving documentation and recordkeeping, and updating preventative maintenance policies, as well as ammonia equipment upgrades and repairs.

CTI Foods, with support from contractors and consultants entrenched in the ammonia refrigeration industry, strives to ensure a safe working environment at the facility for all employees, guests, and visitors.  The facility also plans to improve safety as follows:

  --  Continued involvement of refrigeration and safety personnel in the ongoing development and implementation of the risk management policies.
  --  Participation of key personnel in industry recommended training classes to ensure the facility is aware of evolving industry standards and techniques used to encourage a safety culture at the facility.
  --  Conducting routine RMP / PSM team meetings to ensure any issues identified by facility personnel, refrigeration contractors, or consultants are discussed and addressed.
  --  Conducting a Minimum System Safe

ty Evaluation gap assessment associated with the industry recognized standard (IIAR Standard 9) for existing ammonia refrigeration systems.
  --  Reviewing and auditing the risk management and prevention policies to ensure they are maximizing the facilitys efforts at limiting the risks associated with handling anhydrous ammonia.
